Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: The ELM Survey, Short Period Binary White Dwarfs as Supernova Progenitors, Gravitational Wave Sources, and Probes of Extreme Stellar Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research goal of this work is to detect and characterize very low mass white dwarfs in binary systems, in order to help understand likely Type Ia supernovae progenitors. About 30-50 new systems will be identified and studied with a new census of extremely low-mass white dwarfs identified using the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and the Hyper-Velocity Star Survey. This work will provide critical new insights into the formation and fate of exotic low-mass white dwarfs. It will also give us new tests of General Relativity and tidal evolution in short-period systems.

Understanding the constituents and history of the cosmos lies at the heart of modern astrophysics. In the last 15 years, observations of Type Ia supernovae (SNe) indicate that the expansion of the universe is dominated by dark energy. Until we find the progenitors, it is impossible to understand the systematic uncertainties and to optimize SNe Ia to definitively explore cosmology. The SNe Ia progenitor problem is therefore a key problem in astronomy today, and this research promises to add significant knowledge to our understanding of these exotic systems. The work also has a broad plan for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral involvement in the observations, data analysis, and dissemination of results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have performed a survey to discover merging binary white dwarf systems. Such binaries are predicted to explode (if they are massive enough) in type Ia supernova, which can outshine an entire galaxy. We use these supernovae as standard candles to study the structure and expansion of the Universe, but we still have not found a single progenitor system for these explosions.

Unlike the previous surveys, here we concentrated on the lowest mass white dwarfs observed, since we expect all of these low mass objects to form in binary systems. This is, in fact, what we observe. Almost all of our low-mass white dwarfs (with masses around 20% of the mass of the Sun) are in short period systems with periods less than a day. We discovered around 80 such systems, including 40 of them that will merge within the age of the Universe. We also discovered all of the 7 currently known systems with periods less than an hour. The shortest period systems, with periods of 12 and 20 minutes, emit so much gravitational waves that they are verification binaries for the LISA mission. This means that when the LISA mission is launched, it has to detect the gravitational waves from our two sources. In addition, two of our objects show eclipses; the 12 min system and another 40 min period system. We have watched the eclipses in the 12 min system shift by more than 2 minutes over a few years since the orbit is shrinking slowly as predicted by Einstein's theory of general relativity.

After discovering a large number of these merging binary white dwarfs, we were able to use this sample to estimate the merger rate of such systems in the entire Galaxy. We found that these objects merge at a rate comparable to the exotic, extreme helium stars called R Coronae Borealis stars. Hence, we demonstrated for the first time that most double white dwarfs merge but not explode. Hence,  we still have not found the objects that form Type Ia supernovae, but in the process we discovered the progenitors of two types of exotic objects; interacting AM Canum Venaticorum binary systems and the R Coronae Borealis stars.

Our project provided research opportunities for several graduate and undergraduate students from a variety of backgrounds, and helped us provide outreach activities to different communities throughout the state of Oklahoma.
